title: Curriculum Vitae
text:
Research Interests

Avian pathogenic Escherichia coli (APEC) pathogenesis and vaccine development
Campylobacter jejuni prevalence, antimicrobial resistance, and vaccine candidates
Rapid molecular detection of poultry pathogens (LAMP, qPCR)
Poultry gut microbiome analysis and culturomics
Woody breast myopathy mechanisms in broilers
Food safety and pathogen genomics

title: Li Zhang | Agricultural Microbiomes & Food Safety
text:
Research Focus
Our laboratory integrates agricultural microbiomes, microbial genomics, and bioinformatics to develop practical solutions for pathogen detection, characterization, and control. I work at the intersection of fundamental microbiology and applied food safety, developing tools and knowledge that directly benefit industry, regulatory agencies, and public health.


Advanced Molecular Detection
Developing and validating rapid detection methods including LAMP assays, multiplex qPCR, and real-time PCR for foodborne pathogens. Focus on field-deployable diagnostics for food safety applications.


Agricultural Microbiome
Using culturomics and next-generation sequencing to characterize beneficial and pathogenic microorganisms in food production systems. Identifying probiotic candidates and understanding microbiome-pathogen interactions.


Foodborne Pathogen Genomics
Applying whole-genome sequencing (WGS) and bioinformatics to characterize Salmonella, Campylobacter jejuni, and pathogenic E. coli. Developing high-throughput Oxford Nanopore pipelines for serotyping and MLST analysis of large isolate collections.


Biofilm Formation & Control
Investigating biofilm formation mechanisms in foodborne pathogens under environmental stress conditions. Published studies on Salmonella and Campylobacter biofilms under temperature stress, shear stress, and aerobic/microaerobic conditions.

title: Li Zhang | Agricultural Microbiomes & Food Safety
text:
Funding & Collaboration



Our research is supported by USDA Agricultural Research Service, USDA NIFA, US Poultry and Egg Association, MAFES, and industry partners. I actively collaborate with government stakeholders, food industry partners, and fellow academic scientists across multiple institutions.

title: Join the Lab
text:
Join Our Team



The Zhang Lab is always interested in hearing from motivated students and researchers. We particularly welcome inquiries from individuals with diverse backgrounds and perspectives.

title: Join the Lab
text:
Why Join Us?


Cutting-Edge Research
Work with the latest sequencing technologies and computational methods to solve real-world problems in food safety and public health.


Supportive Environment
Join a collaborative lab culture that prioritizes mentorship, work-life balance, and professional development.


Career Preparation
Develop skills valued in academia, government (CDC, USDA, FDA), and industry through hands-on training and networking opportunities.


Computational Focus
Gain expertise in bioinformatics, data science, and reproducible research practices that are increasingly essential in biology.

title: Join the Lab
text:
What We‚Äôre Looking For
Beyond specific qualifications, successful lab members share these qualities:
‚úì Curiosity ‚Äî Genuine interest in understanding how things work
‚úì Persistence ‚Äî Willingness to troubleshoot and iterate
‚úì Communication ‚Äî Ability to explain your work clearly
‚úì Collaboration ‚Äî Comfort working in a team environment
‚úì Integrity ‚Äî Commitment to honest, rigorous science
‚úì Growth mindset ‚Äî Eagerness to learn new skills
We do not expect you to already be an expert. We will teach you what you need to know.

title: Join the Lab
text:

First Year (Graduate Students)

Lab rotations (if applicable) or immediate project start

Work-Life Balance
We believe in sustainable productivity. The lab has flexible hours, and I do not expect weekend or evening work except near deadlines. Mental health and personal well-being come first.

title: Join the Lab
text:
About Mississippi State


Mississippi State University is a land-grant research university located in Starkville, Mississippi. With strong programs in agriculture, engineering, and the sciences, MSU offers excellent resources for graduate training.
Starkville is a friendly college town with affordable cost of living, mild winters, and a welcoming community. The campus is about 2 hours from Jackson, 3 hours from Memphis, and 2 hours from Birmingham.
Resources:

MSU Graduate School
Starkville Visitors Bureau





MSU Campus

title: Join the Lab
text:
FAQ
Q: Do I need programming experience to join the lab?
A: Not necessarily! For graduate students, we can teach you what you need. However, demonstrating willingness to learn (e.g., taking a free online course) strengthens your application.
Q: Is the GRE required?
A: No.¬†MSU does not require the GRE for most graduate programs.
Q: Can international students apply?
A: Yes! We welcome international applicants. MSU‚Äôs Office of International Services can assist with visa requirements.
Q: What if I‚Äôm interested but not sure about a specific project?
A: That‚Äôs fine! Email Dr.¬†Zhang to discuss your interests and we can identify good fits.

title: Join the Lab
text:
How to Apply

Step 1: Initial Contact
Email Dr.¬†Zhang at l.zhang@msstate.edu with:

Subject line: ‚Äú[Position Type] Inquiry - [Your Name]‚Äù
Brief introduction (1 paragraph)
Why you‚Äôre interested in our research (1 paragraph)
Attached CV/resume

Step 2: Discussion
If there‚Äôs a potential fit, we‚Äôll schedule a video call to discuss your background, interests, and goals.
Step 3: Formal Application
For graduate positions, submit formal application through MSU Graduate School. For postdocs, provide full application materials.
Step 4: Interview
Invited candidates will interview (virtual or in-person) with Dr.¬†Zhang and lab members.








Tips for Strong Applications




Be specific about why our lab interests you (not just generic statements)
Show initiative ‚Äî Have you taken relevant courses? Done independent learning?
Demonstrate fit ‚Äî Explain how your goals align with our research
Proofread ‚Äî Attention to detail matters




Questions not answered here? Email l.zhang@msstate.edu ‚Äî I try to respond within one week.

title: Teaching & Mentoring
text: I am committed to training the next generation of scientists in agricultural microbiomes and food safety. My teaching emphasizes hands-on laboratory skills, advanced molecular methods, and real-world applications of microbiology. I combine fundamental concepts with cutting-edge techniques including bioinformatics, whole-genome sequencing, and molecular diagnostics.

title: Teaching & Mentoring
text: I am committed to training the next generation of scientists in agricultural microbiomes and food safety. My teaching emphasizes hands-on laboratory skills, advanced molecular methods, and real-world applications of microbiology. I combine fundamental concepts with cutting-edge techniques including bioinformatics, whole-genome sequencing, and molecular diagnostics.

title: Teaching & Mentoring
text:
Courses

PO/ADS 8123: Advanced Techniques in Agricultural Microbiome Analysis

Level: Graduate (Ph.D./M.S.) Credits: 3 Semester: Fall (2024, 2025) Format: Lecture + Laboratory
Description: This advanced graduate course covers cutting-edge computational and molecular methods for analyzing microbiome data in agricultural systems. Students learn bioinformatics, 16S rRNA analysis, shotgun metagenomics, culturomics approaches, and nanopore sequencing-based characterization methods.
Learning Objectives:

Design and implement microbiome studies in agricultural and food systems
Process and analyze 16S rRNA and metagenomic sequence data using bioinformatics pipelines
Apply culturomics approaches for bacterial isolation and characterization
Manage large sequencing datasets and implement computational workflows
Critically evaluate microbiome literature and experimental designs

Prerequisites: Graduate standing; basic knowledge of microbiology



PO/FNH 4512/6512: Poultry Product Safety & Sanitation

Level: Undergraduate/Graduate Credits: 2 Semester: Spring (2021‚Äì2025) Format: Lecture
Description: Comprehensive coverage of food safety principles in poultry production and processing. Topics include HACCP, pathogen control, sanitation procedures, regulatory compliance, and emerging food safety technologies.
Topics Include:

HACCP principles and implementation
Pathogen biology (Salmonella, Campylobacter, Listeria, E. coli)
Sanitation and antimicrobial interventions
FDA/USDA regulatory framework
Emerging detection technologies

Prerequisites: Junior standing or instructor permission



PO 4514/6514: Poultry Processing

Level: Undergraduate/Graduate Credits: 3 Semester: Fall 2023 Format: Lecture + Plant Visits
Description: Overview of modern poultry processing operations from live receiving through further processing. Emphasis on food safety integration throughout the production chain.
Topics Include:

Processing plant operations and flow
Slaughter and evisceration procedures
Chilling and antimicrobial treatments
Cut-up and deboning operations
Quality control and food safety




PO 8990: Molecular Techniques in Poultry Research

Level: Graduate Credits: Variable Semester: Fall (2019, 2022) Format: Laboratory-intensive
Description: Hands-on training in molecular biology techniques commonly used in poultry research. Students gain practical experience with DNA/RNA extraction, PCR, qPCR, sequencing library preparation, and data analysis.
Learning Objectives:

Isolate and identify avian pathogens from chicken tissues and environmental samples.
DNA/RNA extraction from diverse sample types
Conventional and real-time PCR optimization
Genotypic and phenotypic characterization of antimicrobial resistance in avian pathogens
Avian immune response analysis

title: Teaching & Mentoring
text:
Mentoring Philosophy
My approach to mentoring includes:

Individual Development Plans (IDPs) ‚Äî All graduate students create and regularly update career development plans
Weekly one-on-one meetings ‚Äî Regular meetings to discuss research progress and challenges
Professional development ‚Äî Support for conference attendance, scientific writing, and career exploration
Hands-on training ‚Äî As a molecular biologist, I personally train students in laboratory techniques
Collaborative environment ‚Äî Lab members support each other and contribute to departmental activities
Work-life balance ‚Äî Expectations that respect personal well-being


Laboratory Training
I provide hands-on training to graduate students throughout the department in molecular biology techniques including:

DNA/RNA extraction and purification
PCR, qPCR, and LAMP assay development
Sequencing library preparation
Bioinformatics analysis

title: Research Programs
text: Our research spans agricultural microbiomes, microbial genomics, vaccine development, and bioinformatics to address challenges in animal health and food safety. We develop rapid molecular detection methods, characterize pathogen biofilms under environmental stress, and apply whole-genome sequencing for epidemiological surveillance. Additionally, we use reverse vaccinology and host-pathogen interactions studies to identify promising vaccine candidates against foodborne and poultry pathogens.

title: Research Programs
text:
Agricultural Microbiome


Overview
The microbiome plays critical roles in food safety, pathogen colonization resistance, and product quality. We apply culturomics and metagenomic approaches to characterize microbial communities in food production systems and identify beneficial microorganisms.


Research Highlights
Culturomics for Beneficial Microbe Discovery

Targeted cultivation and isolation of beneficial bacteria from animal gut microbiomes
Genomic characterization of probiotic candidate isolates
Evaluating colonization resistance effects against foodborne pathogens
Full-length 16S rRNA sequencing for species-level identification

Microbiome-Pathogen Interactions

Gut microbiome associations with pathogen colonization
Effects of dietary interventions on microbiome composition and pathogen resistance
Probiotic supplementation effects on food safety outcomes

Spoilage Microbiome Characterization

Culture-independent metagenomic analysis of spoilage bacteria
Microbiome dynamics during refrigerated storage
Identifying key spoilage organisms for targeted intervention



Key Publications

Wang et al.¬†(2025) Poultry Science ‚Äî Culturomics for probiotic candidate isolation (Minor revision)
Zhang et al.¬†(2021) Poultry Science ‚Äî Cecal microbiota contribute to woody breast myopathy. DOI
Jia et al.¬†(2022) Poultry Science ‚Äî Woody breast myopathy-associated gut microbiome. DOI

title: Research Programs
text:
Advanced Molecular Detection Methods


Overview
Early and accurate detection of foodborne pathogens is critical for food safety management. We develop and validate rapid molecular diagnostic tools including LAMP assays, real-time PCR, and multiplex detection methods for practical application in food safety monitoring.


Research Highlights
LAMP Assay Development

Developed and optimized loop-mediated isothermal amplification (LAMP) assays for Clostridium perfringens detection
Evaluated multiple DNA extraction methods for field compatibility
Validated assay performance across diverse sample matrices
Target: Field-deployable diagnostic systems for food safety applications

Real-Time PCR Methods

Developed TaqMan-based multiplex qPCR for rapid pathogen detection
Cytokine response profiling assays for host-pathogen interaction studies
Validated across tissue, environmental, and food samples

Detection Method Validation

Sensitivity and specificity optimization
Cross-reactivity assessment with related organisms
Performance evaluation under field conditions

Bioluminescent Pathogen Tracking

Construction and characterization of bioluminescent Salmonella Reading strains
Real-time imaging for pathogen tracking and transmission studies
Comparison of outbreak and non-outbreak strain characteristics



Key Publications

Chaudhary et al.¬†(2025) J. Applied Poultry Research ‚Äî DNA extraction method evaluation for LAMP. DOI
Chaudhary et al.¬†(2024) J. Applied Poultry Research ‚Äî LAMP assay optimization for C. perfringens. DOI
Isah et al.¬†(2024) Microbiology Spectrum ‚Äî Construction and characterization of bioluminescent Salmonella Reading outbreak and non-outbreak strains. DOI



Media Coverage

Billion-Dollar Bacteria Breakthrough ‚Äî MAFES Discovers, Winter 2025
AMI Members Develop Rapid Test for Bacterium That Costs Poultry Industry Billions Globally ‚Äî The Microbiologist, April 2025

title: Research Programs
text:
Vaccine Development & Host-Pathogen Interactions


Overview
Vaccines offer a sustainable approach to reducing foodborne pathogen contamination at the source. We apply reverse vaccinology, computational immunoinformatics, and molecular characterization to identify novel vaccine candidates against key foodborne pathogens.


Research Highlights
Reverse Vaccinology Approaches

Pangenome analysis to identify conserved, surface-exposed vaccine targets
In silico prediction of immunogenic antigens
Identified pagP as a potential universal vaccine candidate against pathogenic E. coli
Host-pathogen interaction analysis using cell culture infection models

Campylobacter jejuni Vaccine Candidates

In silico prediction and expression analysis of vaccine candidate genes
BtuB-based immune intervention strategies
Developing challenge models for vaccine efficacy assessment

Host Immune Response Characterization

Cytokine response profiling during infection
Macrophage infection models for pathogen-host interaction studies
Immune pathway analysis for vaccine target validation



Key Publications

Jia et al.¬†(2025) J. Applied Microbiology ‚Äî Reverse vaccinology identifies pagP vaccine candidate. DOI
Poudel et al.¬†(2024) World Poultry Science Journal ‚Äî C. jejuni vaccine development review. DOI
Poudel et al.¬†(2023) Poultry Science ‚Äî Vaccine candidate gene expression analysis. DOI
Ye et al.¬†(2025) Poultry Science ‚Äî Cytokine response dynamics during APEC infection. DOI



Media Coverage

Fowl Play: MSU Scientists Develop Chicken Vaccine to Combat Bacteria ‚Äî MAFES Discovers, Summer 2024
Enhancing Food Safety to Feed the World‚Äôs Growing Population ‚Äî WATTPoultry.com, July 2020
Campylobacter Vaccine Research ‚Äî Meatingplace, 2022

title: Research Programs
text:
Whole-Genome Sequencing & Bioinformatics


Overview
Whole-genome sequencing (WGS) has revolutionized foodborne pathogen surveillance and epidemiology. We develop and apply high-throughput sequencing pipelines and bioinformatics workflows for pathogen characterization, outbreak investigation, and antimicrobial resistance profiling.


Research Highlights
Oxford Nanopore Sequencing Pipelines

Developed high-throughput Nanopore-based MLST (multilocus sequence typing) pipeline for large-scale pathogen studies
Characterized >500 E. coli isolates using custom bioinformatics workflows
Implemented O-serogroup typing from long-read sequencing data
Real-time sequencing protocols for rapid pathogen identification

Genomic Epidemiology

Complete genome sequencing of outbreak and non-outbreak Salmonella Reading strains
Pangenome analysis revealing evolutionary clusters and transmission patterns
Virulence gene and antimicrobial resistance profiling from WGS data
Integration of genomic data with epidemiological metadata

Bioinformatics Pipeline Development

Custom pipelines for serotyping, MLST, and virulence profiling
Large dataset management for multi-hundred isolate studies
Automated analysis workflows for routine surveillance applications
High-performance computing (HPC) implementation for scalable analysis



Key Publications

Jia et al.¬†(2024) Poultry Science ‚Äî High-throughput Nanopore MLST pipeline. DOI
Jia et al.¬†(2024) Microbiology Resource Announcements ‚Äî Complete genome sequences of pathogenic E. coli. DOI
Li et al.¬†(2020) J. Global Antimicrobial Resistance ‚Äî Complete genome sequence of multidrug-resistant avian pathogenic E. coli strain APEC-O2-MS1170. DOI
Isah et al.¬†(2024) Microbiology Spectrum ‚Äî Genomic characterization of Salmonella Reading. DOI
Poudel et al.¬†(2022) Microbiology Resource Announcements ‚Äî Complete C. jejuni genome sequences. DOI

title: Research Programs
text:
Foodborne and Poultry Pathogen Epidemiology


Overview
Understanding the epidemiology of foodborne and poultry pathogens‚Äîincluding prevalence, antimicrobial resistance patterns, and transmission dynamics‚Äîis essential for developing effective control strategies. We conduct surveillance studies and molecular epidemiology research on key foodborne and poultry pathogens.


Research Highlights
Campylobacter jejuni Surveillance

Characterized C. jejuni prevalence and antimicrobial resistance in production systems
Identified multi-drug resistance patterns and associated genetic determinants
MLST-based epidemiological tracking
Virulence gene profiling across diverse isolate collections

Salmonella Transmission Dynamics

Constructed bioluminescent Salmonella Reading strains for real-time tracking
Evaluated vertical transmission potential in poultry production
Characterized outbreak vs.¬†non-outbreak strain genomic differences

Antimicrobial Resistance Profiling

Phenotypic susceptibility testing combined with WGS-based resistance prediction
Identification of resistance genes and mobile genetic elements
Trends in antimicrobial resistance over time and production systems



Key Publications

Poudel et al.¬†(2024) Poultry Science ‚Äî C. jejuni prevalence and AMR in NAE broilers. DOI
Poudel et al.¬†(2022) Microbiology Spectrum ‚Äî AMR molecular characterization. DOI
Li et al.¬†(2021) Poultry Science ‚Äî Effects of in ovo probiotic administration on the incidence of avian pathogenic E. coli in broilers and evaluation of virulence and antimicrobial resistance properties. DOI
Isah et al.¬†(2024) Poultry Science ‚Äî Salmonella Reading vertical transmission. DOI



Media Coverage

USPOULTRY 2024 Research Newsletter ‚Äî Salmonella Reading transmission dynamics research featured on page 2

title: Research Programs
text:
Foodborne Pathogen Biofilms


Overview
Biofilm formation by foodborne pathogens poses significant challenges for food safety, enabling bacteria to persist on processing surfaces and resist sanitation procedures. We investigate biofilm formation mechanisms, environmental stress responses, and intervention strategies for Salmonella, Campylobacter jejuni, and pathogenic E. coli.


Research Highlights
Campylobacter jejuni Biofilm Formation

Demonstrated that elevated temperatures facilitate C. jejuni biofilm formation under both aerobic and microaerobic conditions
Characterized aerotolerance mechanisms linking survival to food safety risks
Studied biofilm formation as a survival strategy in processing plant environments

Salmonella Biofilm Development

Investigated biofilm formation on food processing surfaces under fluidic shear stress
Characterized expression of biofilm-associated genes under environmental stress
Evaluated different surface materials for Salmonella biofilm resistance
Constructed bioluminescent Salmonella strains for real-time biofilm imaging

Environmental Stress Responses

Gene expression profiling of stress-related genes during biofilm formation
Temperature, oxygen tension, and surface contact effects on biofilm development
Developing science-based intervention strategies



Key Publications

Pokhrel et al.¬†(2024) Poultry Science ‚Äî Temperature effects on C. jejuni biofilm formation. DOI
Thames et al.¬†(2025) J. Applied Microbiology ‚Äî Environmental stress modulates biofilm gene expression (Accepted)

title: Research Programs
text:
Expertise & Capabilities







Area
Skills & Methods




Genomics & Sequencing
Sanger, Oxford Nanopore, Illumina


Bioinformatics
Pipeline development, MLST/serotyping, microbiome, WGS analysis


Molecular Detection
LAMP assay development, qPCR/RT-qPCR, multiplex PCR, primer design


Microbiology
Pathogen isolation/characterization, biofilm assays, antimicrobial susceptibility testing, culturomics


Animal Models
Poultry challenge studies, vaccine efficacy trials, pathogen colonization models, tissue sample collection and analysis


Data Science
Python, R, statistical analysis, database management, HPC computing

Dr.¬†Zhang‚Äôs research focuses on agricultural microbiomes, microbial genomics, vaccine development, and food safety. Ph.D.¬†Students






Sunita Shrestha
Candidate for Ph.D.¬†in Poultry Science
Sunita is working on pathogen genomics and vaccine development strategies for poultry pathogens. Her research focuses on identifying and characterizing vaccine candidates against avian pathogens using reverse vaccinology approaches.
2025 Lallemand Animal Nutrition Scholarship Finalist
Email: ss4440 (at) msstate.edu










Manhong Wang
Candidate for Ph.D.¬†in Poultry Science
Manhong is developing culturomics approaches to isolate and characterize beneficial bacteria from the poultry gut microbiome. His research aims to identify probiotics that can improve poultry health and reduce pathogen colonization.
2024 International Paper Scholarship ($1,500), Mississippi Poultry Association

title: People
text:
M.S. Students






Rita Ugoh
Candidate for M.S. in Food Science
Rita is characterizing spoilage bacteria in catfish using culturomics approaches for the Mississippi Center for Food Safety. Her work aims to improve quality control and extend shelf life in catfish processing.
Email: ru90 (at) msstate.edu










Haley Nabors
Candidate for M.S. in Poultry Science
Haley is investigating antibiotic resistance and multi-drug resistance patterns in Clostridium perfringens isolated from diseased chickens. Her research contributes to understanding antimicrobial resistance in poultry pathogens.
Expected graduation: 2027
Email: hln80 (at) msstate.edu
